review: I went through a Calvino binge/phase thirty years ago - the Cloven Viscount, the Baron in the Trees, but Invisible Cities is a step above. Its sort of a fairy tale that's somehow got its feet on the ground. Its dreamy and detailed at the same time, the way old films would zoom into a new scene through mist or clouds to establish a locale and tone at the same time. Thanks

name: Benjamin Felser
review: A book to be read slowly day by day. As Marco Polo speaks of the cities composing Kublaj Khan’s extensive empire, you yourself find strange connections with the illusive essence of place. A wistful, adventurous and nostalgic journey. Sometimes difficult to follow city after city after city, but I think a few cities a day offers nourishing scenes.

name: Editor Gloria Macaluso
review: Il periodo strutturale di Calvino non l’avevo mai approfondito, a mio gusto decisamente inferiore alle narrazioni di realismo magico. Nelle Città Invisibili si mostra metaforico e obliquo, ogni capitolo ha una conclusione, un ragionamento che spazia dalla socialità al consumismo, dalla globalizzazione all’avventura antropologica.

name: L
review: An acquaintance who teaches Italian Literature at a local university suggested I read this, her favorite book. It contains many fascinating concepts that probably could benefit from an Italian Literature teacher! It seems to be a text that should be read many times, in different orders to begin to understand the patterns, symbolism and themes the author is revealing to the reader.

name: James
review: I can’t tell if what I just read was prose or poetry but either way it was incredible. So many ineffable feelings and ideas compressed into only 140 pages. Vonnegut may think that everything there is to know about life is in The Brothers Karamazov, but I’m halfway convinced that it’s here too, in these 55 Invisible Cities.

name: Rumen Mavrov
review: Най-вероятно проблема е в мен, но не успях да разбера смисъла на тази книга. Разбрах, че Марко Поло опитва да опише Венеция и да свърже всички негови пътешествия с нея...и до там. След "Ако пътник в зимна нощ" имах огромни очаквания за втората книга на Кавлино, с която ще се срещна, но за съжаление съм разочарован.

name: Emily Shearer
review: One of those books that can be read again and again. I read this for the first time between college and kids and it always stayed in my mind as one of the most imaginative pieces of literature, expansive and layered and allegorical and creative. Reading it for the second time did not disappoint! Next I will try to tackle "If on a Winter's Night" IN ITALIAN!

name: Merve
review: Açıkçası olay akışına bağlı olmayan hikayeleri pek sevmem ama bu eser bana farklı hissettirdi. Sanki o şehirlerde yaşıyormuscasina canlıydı. Sanki simdiydi, herkesti, bizdik gibi. İlk yarısını okuduktan sonra tam sıkılmaya başlayınca bir şekilde yine de içine çekti, farklıydı 👌*Görünmez Kentler mi yoksa bizim göremediğimiz kentler mi pek emin olamıyor insan*

name: Malu Cicala
review: Wow is all I can really say right now. I know I will look upon this book and reading experience with so much fondness. What a beautifully written piece! It truly blurs the lines between novel and prose creating a truly unique narrative. It takes an extremely creative and masterful mind to have executed this idea so perfectly. Mr. Calvino has earned himself a new admirer!

name: Armando
review: Este libro me hizo querer visitar ciudades desconocidas, remotas y totalmente extraordinarias.Lo más destacado- La prosa me cautivó por completo.- Las discusiones entre Kublai Kan y Marco Polo crearon un puente perfecto para conectar la multitud de ciudades visitadas.- Cada ciudad tenia una "personalidad" distinta pero a la vez poseian similitudes entre sí.- Tengo una debilidad por el "worldbuilding" y Calvino aqui se lucío con cada ciudad que trajó a la vida.Ciudades favoritas- Tamara, Despina, Maurilia, Cloe, Eutropia, Leandra, Clarisa, Eusapia, Andria y BereniceFrases (Son muchas para ponerlas aquí todas)“Hay que guardarse de decirles que a veces ciudades diferentes se suceden sobre el mismo suelo y bajo el mismo nombre, que nacen y mueren sin haberse conocido, incomunicables entre sí.”"La mentira no está en las palabras, esta en las cosas.""Las imágenes de la memoria, una vez fijadas por las palabras, se borran - dijo Polo-. Quizás tengo miedo de perder Venecia de una vez por todas si hablo de ella. O quizás, hablando de otras ciudades, la he ido perdiendo poco a poco."

name: Davidlodge82
review: 3,5 ⭐️ lectura exigente por su prosa algo poética y evocadora. Lo cual en mi caso me desconectaba de la lectura imaginando ciudades inexistentes por eso le pongo más estrellas. Ítalo prevé que no te está llevando a ninguna parte cuando lo está haciendo sin darte cuenta. Es de los libros del autor que menos me ha gustado.

name: stjepan
review: Beautifully written with a unique format and interesting ideas but ultimately a chore one needs to get through despite its short length.Marking some chapters:Cities and Desire 2,5Cities and Signs 1,2,3Thin Cities 1Trading Cities 2, 3Cities and Eyes 1Cities and The Dead 2, 4Continous cities 1, 4, 5Cities and names 5Cities and the sky 3

name: Bianca
review: Esse livro me fez enxergar as tantas cidades dentro da minha propria. Maravilhoso do inicio ao fim. Só nao dou 5 estrelas por que os capítulos excessivamente curtos são irritantes. Quando eu to entrando na vida daquela cidade e to interessada em saber mais o marco vai lá e passa pra próxima, que raiva hehe

name: Martina
review: Ho molto apprezzato i dialoghi tra Polo e l’imperatore dei tartari. Per quanto riguarda le descrizioni delle città, le ho trovate molto poetiche, Polo è un sognatore.Senza dubbio un bel libro anche se a tratti mi ha un po’ annoiata, mi sembrava di leggere un esercizio di stile. Ho questo strano rapporto con Calvino, ne riconosco l’indiscutibile bravura ma non mi fa impazzire.

name: Daniel Lee
review: 보이지 않는 도시들 이탈로 칼비노 (지은이), 이현경 (옮긴이)   민음사   2007-02-25산문 시 같은 소설포스트모더니즘 적이라고 하는데나는 그냥 활자를 읽어 나가는 거 같다일반적인 소설 형식과는 확연히 다르고 읽어도 무슨 내용인지 이해가 잘 안됨마르코 폴로와 쿠빌라이 칸의 대화로 이루어진 소설인데 대화가 선문답 같다복제된 공간, 사물, 사람을 종종 언급한다. 벌써 떠나고 싶어졌습니다.“원할 때면 언제라도 다시 비행기를 탈 수 있습니다." 사람들이 제게 말했습니다.“하지만 당신은 트루데와 완전히 똑같은 또 다른 트루데 에 도착하게 될 겁니다. 세상은 시작도 없고 끝도 없는 하 나의 트루데로 뒤덮여 있을 뿐이고 단지 공항의 이름만 바 뀔 뿐입니다.”

name: Julian Dones
review: I enjoyed the book. Very poetic and easy to follow. I rather believe that these two individuals talking are people who are playing at being such historical characters, but not the characters themselves. I enjoyed the book, but it was not mind blowing. Not sure if I should read more from this author. Maybe one more. Maybe I should read him in Italian. Will see. Cheers

name: Ger Stormchaser
review: Un librito maravilloso, donde Calvino habla de la condición humana a través de sus ciudades imaginarias y quienes la habitan.Si no le pongo puntaje perfecto es porque hay ciertos conceptos que se repiten a lo largo del libro, perdiendo algo de magia.Vale la pena escuchar los relatos que Marco Polo le hace a Kublai Kan: tal vez estemos viviendo en una de esas ciudades y aun no nos enteramos.

name: Razielsghost
review: I respected the talks between characrers much more than the invisible cities themselves. Frequently being lost in authors descriptions this book went way over my head and will probably be quickly forgotten. Though for such a fast read, rven that isn't too bad and im sure some parts will stay with me.

name: Eugene Snegov
review: Сборник коротких фантазий о вымышленных городах, непохожий ни на что - разве что по настроению чем-то напомнивший "Сто лет одиночества". На первый взгляд кажется, что ничего бессмысленней описаний несуществующих городов (с другой стороны, чем они хуже существующих?) и придумать нельзя, но это не так. Каждый город рассказывает свою историю, хотя ближе к концу от этого буйства фантазии начинаешь слегка уставать, как устаешь от затянувшегося путешествия.

name: Kristina
review: „Net ir Raisoje, liūdesio mieste, driekias nematoma gija, kuri akimirkai sujungia vieną gyvą būtybę su kita ir išsinarplioja, paskui vėl išsidriekia tarp judančių taškų, piešdama vis naujus skubrius ornamentus taip, kad tam nelaimingame mieste kas sekundę, užgimsta laimingas miestas, nė nenutuokiantis, kad egzistuoja.“

name: Reader
review: Calvino is great at playing with different levels: reality, story, story within the story, reality within the story… Each of the cities is a metaphor of the World we live in. Compared to his other pieces, though, this one feels a bit cold, as if experimentation about the form took priority about experimentation about the content

name: Chloe
review: I just could not get into this book. It's definitely a me thing and not the book itself, but I just didn't like it and don't even want to keep reading past page 3. This is more poetry than anything else. I was hoping for a more historical-fiction-esque read, but the way this is written couldn't hold my attention. DNF.

name: Sophia
review: This would be a fantastic book to use for writing prompts: take one of the city descriptions and write a story that takes place in it. The description is incredible. But… city descriptions do not a story make. Don’t remember where I heard about this book, but am not invested enough to finish it. (Despite how short it is.)

name: Mike Hartnett
review: I really hated this. I plodded through, hoping I would find some meaning or adjust to the dull, surface-scratching descriptions of what felt like a thousand fictional cities. I did not. Repetitive, redundant, pointless. And on top of it, pretentious enough to think all that was worth someone’s time.

name: Natasha
review: "Sa gradovima je kao sa snovima: sve zamislivo može da se sanja, ali i najneočekivaniji san je zagonetka, koja sakriva neku želju, ili njenu suprotnost, strah. Gradovi su, kao i snovi, sazdani od želja i strahova, iako je nit njihovog govora sakrivena, njihova pravila su apsurdna, perspektiva je varljiva i svaka stvar sakriva neku drugu."Italo Kalvino - "Nevidljivi gradovi"

name: Pontius
review: This book really caught me off guard. I really didn't know what to make of it at first, but before I knew it I was so enchanted that I read it all in one sitting. Then a couple months later I read it again, again all in one sitting. Magical, fantastic, surreal - a supremely uplifting and beautiful read.

name: Miriam Garcia
review: Existen ciudades imaginarias con mucho en común con las ciudades reales. Son metáforas de la vida, la muerte, el anhelo, el progreso, los deseos, la ambición y todo aquello que nos lleva a buscar fortuna en una ciudad, a buscar un laberinto en qué perdernos, a buscar donde perder la vida. Es una lectura que se va en un suspiro, me gustó mucho.

name: Ryhan hossain
review: invisible cities is a great book contained of fairy tales about great cities which give various perspective in one's imaginary & realities. The book explores imagination and the imaginable through the descriptions of cities by an explorer, Marco Polo. the Italian maestro's storytelling is very calmative & thought-provoking simultaneously. everyone give a touch .

name: Zeynab Gholizad
review: بزم توصیف، نماد و تخیل است. نسخه‌ی صوتی‌اش را از ایران‌صدا شنیدم فقط کافی بود چشم‌هایم را ببندم و خودم را در مقابل تصاویری که مارکو از شهرها ارائه می‌کرد ببینم. آهنگین و دلچسب... با وجود همه‌ی این‌ها داستان ساکن بود و کم رخداد و خب این چیزی نیست که من در داستان دنبالش باشم. به هرحال دوستش داشتم. نگاهی هنرمندانه و زیرک به شهرها.

name: Parikshit Tomer
review: Sometimes you end up at the top of a building, its been a bad day.In one hand you have a pen and an empty sheet of paper.You can write all your fears and trepidations into that sheet and it will all be fine.On the other hand you have a box of military grade freshly supplied mint condition Acid used to knockout rogue horses.You can only choose oneItalo Calvino chose both

name: Akif Cohen
review: There is a city. Inside this city there is another city. The people are alive, but they also might be dead. But maybe they don’t even exist since we exist. But do we exist since rice cooking women exist? I think of this city I visited before, but then I realize it never existed. Naked women bathing.

name: Rocío
review: Una lectura singular y sencilla que nos invita a reflexionar sobre nuestro presente a partir de un lenguaje poético divino y unas metáforas increíblemente delicadas. Me parece uno de esos libros que gustaría a cualquier persona que tuviera el placer de encontrarlo. Asistir a esta lectura me ha parecido un acontecimiento digno de los relatos de Marco Polo que en ella se encuadran.

name: Mary
review: Στη ζωη φτάνεις σε μια στιγμή κατά την οποία, ανάμεσα στους ανθρώπους που έχεις γνωρίσει, οι νεκροί είναι περισσότεροι από τους ζωντανούς. Και το μυαλό αρνείται να δεχτεί άλλες φυσιογνωμίες, αλλες εκφράσεις: σε όλα τα νέα πρόσωπα που συναντά, αποτυπώνει τα παλιά εκμαγεία, για το καθένα βρίσκει τη μάσκα που του ταιράζει καλύτερα.

name: Joe
review: 2.5. Marco Polo describes made-up cities with whimsical features to Kublai Khan in a format that seems lost between poetry and novel. Perhaps I need to read more about what makes this book so beloved to other readers and critics, but taken merely at face value, I felt lost in the tedium of the city descriptions and unengaged in the two characters’ new agey philosophical discussions.

name: Sofie
review: Kublai Khan and Marco Polo in conversation about travels to cities at the ends of the world - cities like dreams, labyrinths of thought, where perhaps an answer lies at the exit? The plotless narrative has the feel of a poem, and in the beginning, this made me enjoy it less. But then the descriptions come alive, the cities have personalities, they are figures, metaphors, and become filled with substance. In my mind, Calvino breaks ground every time.Irene is a name for a city in the distance, and if you approach, it changes. For those who pass it without entering, the city is one thing; it is another for those who are trapped by it and never leave. There is the city where you arrive for the first time; and there is another city which you leave never to return. Each deserves a different name; perhaps I have already spoken of Irene under other names; perhaps I have spoken only of Irene. (125)

name: Bas Claassen
review: Bring this on your next city trip. By short descriptions of fable-like destinations, the author explores aspects of cities you'd otherwise not notice. All of this is framed by Marco Polo describing the cities he'd seen to Kublai Kahn. It's very elegant in it's form, small page count and short stories. I recommend rereading this every five years

name: Flavio Mello
review: "As cidades invisíveis" é um dos livros mais lindos que já li, me emocionei lendo-o e me emociono agora ao recordar suas passagens. Calvino nunca me desaponta, cada livro seu é como um mundo novo, real e irreal, dotado de infinitos ensinamentos que, como tradições antigas, são repassados através de gerações de leitores.

name: Joel Siemens
review: I heard Calvino once described as dreaming perfect dreams for us, the readers. I find this completely true in Invisible Cities. This book feels like a dream in which you are allowed to levitate off the ground and soar above impossible cityscapes. It’s all mystical, and meaningful even when your not quite sure why. Perhaps the perfect marriage between poetry and fiction.

name: Katya Piccione
review: What seems impossible to render into another language is the specific feminine charisma of the word città, which is not just the grammatical gender, but the true Italian understanding of what a city (or town) is - with all its associations, connotations, feelings... Calvino's stories about the cities remind the man's memories of women - at least in the talks of the Traveler with the Khan...

name: Jared
review: a beautiful experiment in setting that spins small vignettes of dozens of invented cities, and in doing so discovers the relationship between a visionary traveler who misses home and the recumbant emperor who does not really have one. unfortunately, the fatphobia, transphobia, and anti-semitism wear down the allure a fair bit.

name: Jenna King
review: “The city, however, does not tell its past, but contains it like the lines of a hand, written in the corners of the streets, the gratings of the windows, the banisters of the steps, the antennae of the lightning rods, the poles of the flags, every segment marked in turn with scratches, indentations, scrolls.”This book is like a beautiful dream calling for you to see the beauty and strangeness of the world beyond even what is visible to the eye

name: Rowan
review: Reading this from an architectural/city planning perspective was really interesting. Putting aside the fabulism and the author's really chauvinistic attitude towards women, he really captured the spirits of the cities in these little sketches, the big strokes and the tiny details that make a place vibrant, alive, and more than just lines on a map

name: Eric McLean
review: So, I understand why some will read this and think, "this is the most pretentious drivel I have ever read in my entire life." I'm not sure they would be wrong, but I do know that I thoroughly enjoyed it and I think you will get exactly what you expect out of this book. To me, it was a reflection of my mental state and conjured a lot of thoughts and emotions about things completely unrelated. This is a book of philosophy. It is a book that is sometimes deep, but the depth can be an ocean or a puddle depending on how you read the short collection of Marco Polo describing cities that may or may not exist. Fascinating book.

name: Elijah Cohen
review: Wonderful wonderful book. Some of the most beautiful prose I've ever read. I found myself grinning so much while reading this, rereading and contemplating many passages. A style of writing that feels intuitive and natural but that I would hardly bring myself to imagine otherwise. Magnificent conceptions of space, time, structure, relationships, and change. This book has made me happy

name: Pedro Sutter
review: Eu estava meio cansado desses livros com descrições meio eruditas, e num primeiro momento fiquei com pé atrás com o livro. Mas Cidades Invisíveis preencheu meu imaginário com paisagens e pessoas imaginárias, e me fez ter reflexões até então inéditas sobre o fluxo da vida. Gostei demais, recomendo pra qualquer pessoa que se proponha a desbravar o mundo e o próprio interior.

name: señor mosca
review: qué trabajo tan lindo. creo que es una ¿narrativa? con una estructura muy particular, no necesariamente compleja, aunque la forma de describir las ciudades, tanto como conceptos como ideas o locaciones tangibles me parece cautivante. me gustaría revisitarlo de vez en cuando y leer más de italo calvino.

name: Riley Watkins
review: A delightful and unique read. It lies somewhere between poetry and prose and has such great detail and love put into it. Every last city described is easy to picture, almost as if I am sitting with Khan and Polo in the gardens listening in alongside them. It’s not my typical read, but it’s a worthy one and a quick one too.

name: BookLovingLady (deceased Jan. 25, 2023...)
review: For a review in Dutch, see the autumn challenge 2017 of the Netherlands & Flanders group.

name: GRV
review: INVISIBLE CITIESRating 4/5Cities with MemoriesCities with DesiresCities with Signs...A very different kind. The book is more like poetry than a usual novel. But pure imaginary book to read with very visual writing.

name: Millanen
review: Melekosen lyyrinen kertomusten sarja erilaisiin tapoihin kokea kaupunki. Marco Polosta jää erilainen kosketus tämän jälkeen; Herkkä, ihmismäinen, unenomainen. Vain kaupungit, portit, satamat, kapakat, ihmiset kulkemassa niiden kautta ja ohi. Elämisen kaino ohitusleikkaus, fragmentteina.

name: TJ Wilson
review: Reading Calvino is always revitalizing in that he pushes you past what you thought literature could do. He does this in a simple and inviting way. And then, you realize you are reading and rereading like you do with hard and meandering texts. He tricks you. He is good.

name: جلال الدين عقبي
review: ربما علاقتي بالكتاب هذا تقوم على خيبة الأمل ! فبعد أن قرأت اسمه في قائمة ميوزي لأفضل 100 كتاب و وجدته بعد بحث ليس سهلا ، لم أجد في الكتاب ما أردت .ماذا بعد الجو الساحر ، و خلق معنى الإنسان للمدن ؟

name: Ana
review: One of the most stunning books I've read in a long time. Invisible Cities was not only the exact book I needed at this point in my life, but it's also one I know I'll be coming back to for a while.

name: Jo
review: Adventurer Marco Polo recounts tales of the lands and peoples he's seen to Kublai Khan. The descriptions were lovely and intriguing but overall this was just okay as it never felt like it went anywhere plotwise.

name: Brendan Brady
review: such a wonderful, fantastical read with seriously beautiful insights into the strange parts of every day life. i will definitely need to read this again, there is so much packed in all these amazing little tales. loved it!

name: Abby
review: I am giving this book 5 stars not because I absolutely adored it and it is a new favorite book, but because I could reread this multiple times and get something new out of it each time. I did really love this book, and it's one I would own, and revisit every once in a while.

name: Peter Hayes
review: Not so much a novella as a sustained acid trip. Still, fun and engaging and interesting. Oddly, I still have yet to read 'If On a Winter's Night...' Calvino's most well-known novel. This little work is beautiful to read just for the richness of language alone.

name: Nick
review: A dreamlike narration describing many cities that are in fact one. The dialogue between Marco Polo and Kublai Khan provides poignant, pivotal thoughts throughout. It's a book that seems to go everywhere yet nowhere.

name: Gabriella
review: A must read in Calvino's epic library of philosophical, scientific, mind-bending, insightful, literary genius. So much can be said with few words when someone is truly eloquent. Other recommendations--> the Complete Cosmicomics!

name: Jasmine Papillon-Smith
review: Incredible. I've read it a half-dozen times and will probably continue to re-read it regularly until I die. It's exceptionally thought-provoking and great for getting yourself out of the boring box that is your brain and thinking creatively.

name: Maria
review: Nunca pense que un libro tan corto me consumiera tanto, yo no acostumbreo leer poesia. Es como una pequeña joya de origami, cada delicado dobles amerita contemplacion, una reflexion, una peqeuña obsesion...

name: Rininta
review: Kaya detail, mudah membangun kota-kota rancangan italo calvino dalam pikiranmu dalam bentuk visual.Tapi lain dengan isi ceritanya, kota dengan sifat-sifatnya, disembunyikan rapi, tidak mudah menangkap maksudnya dalam sekali baca.

name: Mark Hall
review: Brilliant imagery and imagination. Sometimes it took me away, a few times it put me to sleep. Not a page turner. It took me a few months to savor it, but I'm glad I did. Fred Bassetti would have loved this book.

name: Gloria Kaszyczky
review: Particolare. Mi è piaciuto quasi quanto Se una notte d'inverno un viaggiatore. Calvino ha una capacità straordinaria di portarti a vedere luoghi fantastici e contemporaneamente a farti riflettere sulla complessità dell'uomo e sulle sue paranoie.

name: Tiff Gibbo
review: Finished this while travelling through cities at a rate of 2 or 3 a week. Was a great and very amusing companion for those bored moments on planes/trains/buses/waiting for check in. Beautifully written and very whimsical.

name: lyfos
review: hard bedtime reading: dense stories; beautiful, intricate sentences make it hard to understand in a sleepy daze. but the effort put in is worth it. pair with the play 'the late wedding' by christopher chen.

name: Debjeet Bhattacharjee
review: Calvino criticizes dictatorship and capitalism. Calvino beautifully implements Polo as a storyteller providing tales of cities to the worrisome Khan, who aspires to retain and govern a mighty kingdom but cannot.

name: Cat
review: A strange and special book. One of a kind. Poetry, meditation, magic. It takes a while to get used to the format, but I am sure that this is a book I will come back to again and again. There is a profound reflection upon humanity that runs through it.

name: Ben Herman
review: Incredible micro-fiction style. Read most of it on an airplane in between dozing off and it really helped the dreamy nature of the narrative. Plus the whole Marco Polo/Kublai Khan aspect that kept the book together was a really interesting concept.

name: Mahendran
review: A delightful read. A genre agnostic and eminently quotable book. I read this in small doses over 2 weeks , mostly after long exhausting days at work and found the read to be soothing. The segments with conversation between Marco polo and Kubhlai Khan are particularly wonderful , replete with lovely quotes. its a book that deserves multiple reads.

name: Noah Winthrop
review: Perhaps the strangest book I've encountered in my short life. 'Invisible Cities' is a collection of descriptions, abstractions, and memories told from alternating narrations, which celebrate exploration in less than 200 pages.

name: Mason
review: A lyrical examination of how we process memory and difference in the physical world. Calvino‘s short sketches of cities across empires reveal how very similar we are in the impulse to preserve a bit of our past.

name: Jesse
review: This was a very easy and interesting read.Incredibly creative, Calvino does an excellent job of painting imaginative portraits for the reader. There is a bit more going on here than Marco Polo just recounting his travels. It's a lot of fun.

name: Lau
review: Much like Kahlil Gibran in the spiritual realm, Italo Calvino, weaves a fable of the types of fantastic cities and lands you wished and wondered about as a child. Only to have you reveal to yourself that they are the land on and city in which you live.

name: Matt Wang
review: “‘Memory’s images, once they are fixed in words, are erased,’ Polo said. ‘Perhaps I am afraid of losing Venice all at once, if I speak of it. Or perhaps, speaking of other cities, I have already lost it, little by little.’”

name: Kevin Macdonald
review: Preemptively rating this 5 stars because I’m going to finish it either tonight or tomorrow and it is AMAZING. I’ll be writing more about it on my instagram profile (@kevinsreadfeed) and possibly on my website as well. :)

name: Agnese
review: Katrs šajā grāmatā var atrast pilsētas, kas viņam pazīstamas un tuvas, pilsētas, kurās patverties, un pilsētas, no kurām izvairīties. Un beigu beigās liriskais stāstījums Marko Polo balsī nav par pilsētām, bet tiem, kas šīs pilsētas veido.

name: Linda Kenny
review: This is a book to put on the re-read shelf.A conversation between Kublai Khan and Marco Polo which consists of descriptions of cities which Polo has visited in his travels or has he? Loaned to me by my son-in-law.

name: Olivia Merrill
review: Invisible Cities makes you think of places you've lived in your whole life & the kind of places you'd like to visit, and how those things are caught in your relationships with space, people, and yourself.

name: Drpsychorat
review: This was one of the most unique but satisfying books I have ever read. Strange, but well written and full of mostly pleasant insights, it kept me peaceful and content. No doubt I will return to it for fresh insight into the human condition.

name: Darya
review: Calvino is a perfect postmodernist because his mind just naturally operates in paradoxes, half-jokes, nods and winks and nudges that on a whim transform into melancholic musings on the nature of modern cities and the life within them.

name: Luis Francisco Palacios Martínez
review: Relatos donde las ciudades se convierten en poesía. Marco Polo le habla a Kubilai Kan sobre ciudades descubiertas, ciudades imaginarias, que se van creando a sí mismas.Arquitectos y urbanistas, dense.

name: Sumit Shetty
review: A very hard read. I found myself slogging through the language used in some of the chapters. Some chapters I wished I could stop reading this book, but it's the magic of Calvino that you know there will be some thing great coming up. All around a great read but in installments, for me at least

name: JustCallMeClint
review: I don't know why I liked this way better on the second reading.There are two reasons that might explain this impression: do books affect people or do people affect books...I know, I know, how pretentious of me, but I can't help it, goddamn it.

name: RC
review: A lucid, disorienting dream, one that feels at once unshakably familiar and strange. The cities Marco Polo describes to Kublai Khan are fantastic, impossible cities we’ve never seen but have always known. Beyond Calvino’s intoxicating imagery are profound observations about memory and language.

name: Evelina
review: Města v představách. Člověk by nejradši ze všeho vyrazil na cestu a pokoušel se všechna ta tajemná zákoutí plná granátových jablek a třásní na sedlech velbloudů hledat. I když ví, že nejsou, nebo naopak, že je může najít i na zaplivaném náměstíčku pod oknem.

name: Zach Thomas
review: A true journey through the modern city in a historical context. If you’re looking for a break from a typical narrative structure, this will be your new favorite read. It’s thought provoking, insightful, and beautifully written.

name: Caroline Payne
review: "Memory's images, once they are fixed in words, are erased," Polo said. "Perhaps I am afraid of losing Venice all at once, if I speak of it. Or perhaps, speaking of other cities, I have already lost it, bit by bit." - Italo Calvino, Invisible Cities

name: Kimberly
review: Good experimental fiction, though it is purposefully confusing – it is meant to make you think and makes little sense if you approach it like a traditional book. Still trying to comprehend it in some way, but I am sure that is part of the point. I recommend it.

name: Martin Ridgway
review: This is wonderfully odd.Marco Polo describes a whole lot of cities to Kublai Khan under a variety of headings like 'Cities and the Dead'. A couple of the cities have airports, skyscrapers, radio masts.Poetry, bizarre, magical.

name: Sam Klemens
review: Yeah, I don't know. Parts of it are very beautiful, no doubt. Parts made me think. But I thought the second half was just too much. It didn't seem honest or insightful or inspiring, it felt to me tedious. Still, I would probably read more of his work.

name: Greg Bem
review: Beautiful book with beautiful writing. How did I not read this sooner I'd heard about it growing up but never even ventured forth after reading the more esoteric writings of Calvino. But I'm glad I finally turned to Invisible Cities properly. Look forward to revisiting again, and again, and again.

name: Abhishek Kona
review: Its a hybrid of poetry and prose. Calvino packs a lot in one sentence, perhaps I should read this much slowly to appreciate the weight. In my first read "I did not get it".It was approachable and I could complete it though.

name: J
review: Less a novel then a series of sketches, much like Pessoa's most famous book, this might be one of Calvino's most famous works, which is a curious status, as there is no plot, and character exists only as a device for more paragraphs about cities, real and imagined.

name: Yinpei
review: 在旅行途中重读了这本书，却在结束时邂逅了一个“真实的”的“看不见的城市”。Arrecife的小巷，镌刻着伊西多拉的名字；城中的湖水如镜，倒映着岸边彩色的房屋，独木舟静静躺在水上，时间在此静止，让我想起瓦尔德拉达；湖边餐厅水塘边数十米长的白色鲸鱼骨，就仿佛是《老人与海》里沙滩上的鱼骨的影子。你所看到的城市，正如可汗所听见马可波罗对于他旅途中所见城市的叙述，你看见的，是你的经历、你的眼睛构建的属于你的城市。看不见的城市，正像是每一个城市，马可将威尼斯融入每一所光怪陆离的城市，而那也正是所有城市的影子。或者你说，那是我们每个人的命运和一生，也不错。

name: Anon E.
review: I have no idea what this book was about. It felt like a too-long poem. I couldn’t get past the lack of plot and the page-long sentences. Probably wouldn’t have finished if this adds not a bookclub selection.

name: Bowdoin
review: Reader in group- One of my favorite books is Invisible Cities by Italo Calvino. Translated from the original Italian, it follows the surreal conversations between fictionalized versions of Marco Polo and Kublai Khan. Divided into simple sections titled like, "Cities and Memory" or "Cities and the Dead," Polo describes the interesting places he has (possibly) encountered. Each short episode challenges the way one looks at cities and the people who live in them. The book is both simple and complex, and touches on a number of subjects like communication and human nature. It's a short read is worth diving into.

name: Liam Klenk
review: Definitely a great work of literature. Intellectual, thought-provoking, and quite beautifully written. But also definitely a book you need to read when you have lots of time to focus on it. It's not an easy piece of entertainment and there is so much depth in those pages.

name: Duarte Magalhães
review: The story tells of the explorer Marco Polo and his attempts to describe to the ruler Kublain Khan the various cities of his extensive empire. Or does it? Do these cities exist? Have they existed and ceased to be? Have they not yet come into existence? Soon we realise that all these cities, each with its peculiarities that resemble our own while retaining a uniqueness that is absolutely out-worldly, exist not in a physical empire but in an empire entrapped in the imagination of the two interlocutors, being thus limitless.

name: Zac Fynn
review: "Memory's images, once they are fixed in words, are erased" Polo said. "Perhaps i am afraid of losing Venice all at once, if i speak of it. Or perhaps, speaking of other cities, I have already lost it, little by little."

name: T.J. Puritz
review: Beautiful language and imagery. The novella does show some of the friendship between Kublai Khan and Marco Polo, but do not read this for the historical background. This would be time spent for pleasure of the written word.

name: Tashfeen
review: There are several living characters in this novel, but only two of them speak, and they're the most uninteresting one's. The cities are described in such a way, that you can swear that their souls are dancing in your mind, from their different scents, down to the pores on their streets.My initial thought when I began reading was of caution, it is a translated work after all, not everything translates well, especially worlds where your senses are stoked, but the English words contained no barrier to my understanding, to having my intellect poked and prodded.I do have one caveat, if you have a list of places you want to travel to, be prepared to add all the locations you'll discover here, and then be prepared to weep when you realize that you will have traveled to them all once you've finished your reading.

name: Kang-Chun Cheng
review: really really beautiful, even with rereading page after page there's no doubt calvino is far too complex for me. so a star taken selfishly aback for all the non-literary geniuses out there who just... can't seem to follow, but get the sense that this is an absolute masterpiece

name: علا حنفية
review: كل الأساطير المبعثرة و الرموز الخفية .. تدركها بلا وعي ..ثم بالكاد تستطيع التعبير عنها .. تنهي الكتاب وأنت تحمل في رأسك كتلة متشابكة من الزمان والمكان والشعور .. هذا الكتاب ليس قصة أحداث .. إنها أماكن تعيش في داخلك رغبة عارمة بأن أقرأ شيئا آخر للكاتب 🌸

name: Mishi_msv
review: از ماركو پرسيد:" روزى كه تمام نشانه ها را بشناسم، عاقبت خواهم توانست مالك امپراطورى خود باشم؟"مرد ونيزى پاسخ داد:" عاليجناب، در اين فكر نباش: آن روز خودت نيز نشانه اى خواهى بود در ميان نشانه هاى ديگر."

name: Richard
review: Intriguing, thought-provoking, but ultimately often puzzling. I’ve heard many describe this book so lovingly and admiringly...I’m sure I missed out on much of its brilliance. Nonetheless one I wouldn’t mind revisiting at some point.

name: Maria Laura Runchina
review: «Anche le città credono d'essere opera della mente o del caso, ma né l'una né l'altro bastano a tener su le loro mura.D'una città non godi le sette o settantasette meraviglie, ma la risposta che dà a una tua domanda.»

name: Maga Torres
review: ¿Una novela? ¿Una serie de cuentos? ¿Poesía en prosa? ¿Un ensayo sobre el hombre contemporáneo? ¿Filosofía existencial? Si, no, cada uno y todos juntos. Definitivamente un libro para soñar y para sentirnos vivos.

name: Cheryl
review: This is a really unusual book, particularly the structure itself. If you are interested in the time period and in particular Marco Polo and Kublai Khan, it puts a little different spin on their relationship.

name: Maiya
review: This was one of those books that left me unsure how much of it was brilliant and how much of it was pretty looking mumbo jumbo. It was quite interesting for a while, but ultimately too repetative. And I fell asleep twice trying to finish the last 20 or so pages...

name: José Ignacio ZG
review: Estético, sugestivo, creativo, instructivo, sugerente, profundo e interrogante. Me sigue sorprendiendo cuánto pueden llegar a transmitir las ''simples'' palabras cuando propiamente escogidas y encadenadas.

name: CNicholson
review: Worth sticking with this. The format is unusual and perhaps unsettling at first but every chapter is a lesson in word-craft and the theme develops like a slowly unspooling thread reflecting the artistry of a great storyteller.

name: Gerko
review: Mijn favoriete stad is Leonia, dat zich iedere dag verfrist en vernieuwt, maar in werkelijkheid bestaat uit een samenklontering van haar afval - 'de schubben van haar verleden smelten aaneen tot een kuras dat niet afgedaan kan worden'. Is Venetië in dit boek niet metafoor aan een mens?

name: Lori
review: The imagery is beautiful, but the story goes nowhere and is hard to follow. It felt like someone trying to explain their dream......beautiful and profound to the teller, but lost in translation for the listener.

name: Gerardo Mauleón
review: - Las imágenes de la memoria, una vez fijadas por las palabras, se borran - dijo Polo -. Quizá tengo miedo de perder a Venecia de una vez por todas si hablo de ella. O quizá hablando de otras ciudades la he ido perdiendo poco a poco.

name: アキ
review: All these cities are metaphor; it seems as if speaking in metaphor makes things easier, for our language itself is a metaphor as well. Indeed it is a fantastic book. Worth reading, and I am willing to reread it.

name: Fausto Lammoglia
review: Come al solito, Calvino da sorprendere. Ogni città è un viaggio dentro se stessi, per cogliere qualche nuovo aspetto. Perdersi nei viaggi fantastici di Marco/Italo e nei dialoghi con Kublai è qualcosa di stupendo.

name: Bas
review: Heel mooi geschreven (en goed vertaald). Een serie miniatuurtjes die met meesterhand zijn gesneden en samen een wonderlijk geheel vormen. Niet te snel lezen, maar lekker rustig, een paar steden per keer. Je zou hiervoor het boek van Marco Polo kunnen lezen waar dit op geïnspireerd is (Il Milione).

name: Mike Radack
review: Will read a thousand explanations for what I just read and then will hopefully re-read and re-read for many years to come. Or maybe I have already read it and this most recent reading was the re-reading?

name: Chiara Peroni
review: Sono una lettrice semplice: leggo "Calvino", metto 5 stelle.(Anche se in realtà continuo a preferire i racconti con una trama ben definita alle raccolte più oniriche quali questo libro o le Cosmicomiche.)

name: Caroline Sol (IG - Drinks & Livros)
review: Em vez de uma linha narrativa clássica, o livro é em sua maioria constituído de descrições de cidades, das mais lindas às mais terríveis. São fascinantes! O capítulo final, um diálogo de Marco polo e kublai Khan, é maravilhoso!

name: Josh
review: After about 100 pages, it started to feel familiar and a bit monotonous, but there were still great lines, ideas, etc in the latter half. By putting it down for the day and coming back the next, I was able to enjoy it again. Probably best read little by little.

name: Mandewi
review: 4,5 bintangLebih mirip esai karena isinya deskripsi mengenai berbagai kota. Esai fiksi. Gambaran kota yang, menurut cerita buku ini, disampaikan oleh Marco Polo kepada Kublai Khan. Yang keren dari buku ini ya deskripsinya itu. Sungguh indah, ku tak sanggup berkata-kata.

name: Xuân Diệu
review: Những thành phố vô hình của một nhà văn Ý với những dòng chữ gấu đọc không bỏ sót từ nào. Vi vu những âm thanh sáo diều, chỉ sợ bỏ qua điều gì đó mà ôm tiếc nuối trong lòng. Hơn 50 thành phố qua lời kể của một thương gia du ngoạn khắp nơi.

name: Martyn Hunter
review: This is the second book by Calvino that I've been very excited to read and then not enjoyed at all. I can see that his writing is intelligent and well done but I just don't enjoy reading it. This is one of those books that I didn't enjoy but I can understand why someone else would.

name: Duncan Vicat-Brown
review: I think I'm ready to say that Calvino is very smart and admirable and I have enormous respect for his books that bore the absolute life out of me. Like reading a great book but only the first two paragraphs of every chapter.

name: Ana Rmz
review: Un italiano fabrica los recuerdos de otro, Marco Polo, en conversaciones inventadas con el rey de los tártaros describe sus viajes por lugares inventados y sus imposibles funcionamientos.Colección de viñetas interesantes, imágenes vívidas, a veces divertidas, otras tristes, siempre poéticas.

name: Jess
review: Started reading the book, then lost it, then could only find the audiobook at my local library. I liked the book more as an audiobook. The narrator does a great job with the rhythm of the words and makes them come alive.

name: Luke
review: Marco Polo tells Kublai Khan of his travels, describing the cities he has visited. Interesting in parts but seems to drag on a bit and a lot of it is quite samey. Not as good as other Calvino books I've read.

name: Ash Rao
review: "...the jam of past, present, future that blocks existences calcified in the illusion of movement: this is what you find at the end of your journey."Reading this book is like floating on a cloud. I expect to read this over and over and over again-- it's absolutely stunning.

name: Shaun
review: Not much to say about this one. Read it because it was on a Top 1,000 Books list. Didn’t care for it. Could give no rating, a single-star, or two stars (my standard), but… I’ll go with… no rating. Just not for me.

name: Simone S
review: Uno dei libri più belli di Italo Calvino, e visto che parliamo di Calvino, probabilmente uno dei libri più belli mai scritti. Mi sono perso tra le sue pagine e nelle vie delle splendide città da lui immaginate.

name: Robyn Everard
review: The imagination used to create this outstanding piece is a wonder. So much detail, so many unique designs. And more astonishing than that is the message behind the words, the thoughts provoked by such an expression of freedom.

name: Yesmo
review: Its beautifully written but I feel like it's something that I'll have to re-read to appreciate fully. Maybe even more than once.It was difficult to read because it's just basically describing places but then it was interesting because of how creative Calvino is. I dunno.Weird book.

name: Rulenneclarissa
review: Where do I even begin with describing this book. Really, the only concrete thing I can say is that it's beautiful. I'll be revisiting the images of cities described for a long time - possibly re-reading bits here and there too.

name: Spyros Balas
review: Αριστούργημα, Αριστούργημα, Αριστούργημα,ο μόχθος σου, που δίνει μορφή στην επιθυμία, παίρνει από την επιθυμία τη μορφή της, κι εσύ νομίζεις ότι έχεις κατακτήσει την Αναστασία ενώ δεν είσαι παρά ο σκλάβος της. Απόσπασμα από το βιβλίο, δεν υπάρχει άλλος τρόπος να περιγράψω αυτό που διάβασα.

name: incipit mania
review: IncipitNon è detto che Kublai Kan creda a tutto quel che dice Marco Polo quando gli descrive le città visitate nelle sue ambascerie [...]Le città invisibili Incipitmania

name: Zdenko Somorovsky
review: Bavila ma táto kniha. Vraciam sa k nej keď mám chuť odletieť mysľou niekam do ďalekých a neviditeľných miest. Nečíta sa to na jeden dych, ale človek si užíva tu fantáziu a krásnu predstavivosť autora. Skvelé na inšpiráciu!

name: Victoria
review: Unlike many other books, it’s difficult to explain Invisible Cities. It’s beautifully written prose detailing an array of cities. It’s littered with robust diction and vibrant imagery. Personally, I found it interesting to notice what sentences, paragraphs, and cities resonated most with me.

name: Augustine Deppmeier
review: The style of the book was very unique. The short chapters really flew by when you are in the zone. I knew the ending, which probably made the book a little more anticlimactic. However I will probably reread the book due to the dense symbolism.

name: Garrett
review: This became my new favorite, I cannot articulately explain why I love this book so— but I can attempt to reach an approximation. I love surrealism, and Invisible Cities is surrealist to its core, but ties said surrealism into meaningful thoughts and ideas.

name: Hind
review: I like the concept, and the format, but the city descriptions didn’t really resonate with me. I found myself often distracted while reading them, and only seldom did they conjure up an image in my mind. I wish borges had written this instead.

name: Luciano Filho
review: Um dos melhores livros que já li. É impressionante a criatividade do autor e sua versatilidade no uso dos recursos linguísticos e literários para criar imagens magníficas de cidades possíveis (e invisíveis!). Vale cada minuto da leitura!

name: Bene Vogt
review: I’m extremely certain any attempts at interpreting this would fall hilariously short so I’ll just keep that to myself. Anyway, a book unlike anything else I’ve ever even heard of, funny, touching, thought provoking, sad , amazing.

name: Caedi
review: The perfect book to read aloud, and the perfect book to come back to time and time again. Invisible Cities is an allegory about the ideas we superimpose onto the world around us - the cities we build and carry with us.

name: Naomi
review: Each sentence carries so much weight. Even though it's a short book, it took a while for me to get through. I needed to process each cities description for a while before venturing on to the next one.

name: Bridget
review: Urban poetry, a beautiful piece of work by Italo Calvino. The cities he describes remind you of your own travels and dream of future cities you’ve yet to experience. It’s the type of book in which it’s easy to imagine that the contents may change the next time you open it.

name: Dick Holder
review: Ehhh it was a little boring for me. I don't think short stories are really my thing, but I did find some meaningful quotes out of it. I felt things a couple of times... which is like kinda the point of reading. Mostly I read it so I can sound pretentious during any book discussion.

name: Matteo Guainazzi
review: "Anche le città credono di essere opera della mente o del caso, ma né l'una né l'altro bastano a tener su le loro mura. D'una città non godi le sette o settantasette meraviglie, ma la risposta que dà a una tua domanda.". Poesia in prosa.

name: Russ
review: Abstract to the point of verbose, with ungainly prose that takes more effort than I am willing to expend in order to get to the cruxes of what he's talking about. Maybe next time, in the midst of the inferno...

name: Lucie
review: A lot of this book went over my head - the writing is so descriptive and philosophical. That being said, some sentences just fly.I probably should have read this at a slower pace to fully appreciate the prose.

name: Abby Meyer
review: I loved Invisible Cities for its transportive, poetic style. The narrative takes form as a conversation between the great Mongol emperor Kublai Khan and a young Marco Polo, whose stories of far-flung, fantastic places hide within them a deep understanding of humanity and its desires.

name: Garuda Guru
review: Necessário para o escritor que quiser escrever descrições essenciais. Obra-prima indiscutível. O tradutor, infelizmente, é um imbecil. Mas o livro é maravilhoso e a tradução está mais que satisfatória.

name: Dora Carson
review: This book is a series of exquisite vignettes of imaginary cities. The tales are tied together with the idea that Marco Polo is describing them to Kublai Khan. While the language and images are beautiful, I would have liked more of a story connecting the descriptions.

name: Noah
review: i kind of thought it would be like some sick cyberpunk scifi, but instead it was... well its kind of hard to describe tbh, but its definitely more poetic in nature... a one-of-a-kind book, a short read, but best read on a contemplative summer afternoon perhaps

name: meltem
review: don't know why but Polo's descriptions of cities reminded me of Stefon from SNL's NY hottest new clubs reviews. "the world's hottest new city is Smeraldina. this city has Eveything:..." so yeah . nice book

name: S Presnail
review: Didn't know what to expect from this. All a bunch of small vignettes of fictional cities told through Marco Polo to Kublai Khan. Surreal, anachronistic, and lyrical. Very well thought out and written. 4.5

name: Paul Taylor
review: Plenty of highly respected, literary people hold this book in high regard; I do not. I could guess what message the book seeks to convey but cannot be bothered to do so; I will leave that to others and move on.

name: Saara
review: If it wasn't such a short book, I would have quit it. I hated every second of it. It made me feel confused and angry and analytical. Felt like I was watching "The Tree of Life". Easily the worst book I've read, in years.

name: Olivia Yerovi
review: Ciudades invisibles que nos habitan a todos, así lo siento. Este es un libro peculiar, que no contiene una historia en sí, sino que presenta un conjunto de ciudades inventadas y surrealistas, descritas con un lenguaje lleno de imágenes y metáforas. Para leer y releer con pausa.

name: Enhee Tsoodol
review: Энд дурдсан хотуудыг хэрхэн дүрсэлж, буулгах нь та бидний уран төсөөллөөр хэмжигдэх буй за. “Аян дайн, арилжаа наймааны үйл хэрэг биднийг хэчнээн хол замд хөтөлсөн ч анир чимээгүй агаар, зурвасхан тасалдах яриа, үргэлжийн мөнх давтагдах энэ л үдшийн сэлүүхнээр өөрсдийгөө хүрээлүүлж явна...”

name: Nikolai
review: Книгата е приятна, но не беше особено вълнуваща. А със самата си структура и концепция е малко трудна за възприемане.Интересното е, че разказите за невидимите градове, в които Марко Поло никога не е бил, малко ми напомняха за "познатите" на Сароян от "Некролози", които той никога не е срещал.

name: Lindsay (novelandink)
review: 3.5I started off absolutely loving this, but that decreased as I went. But I’m still perplexed and confused about it in the best way possible. I very rarely read something and immediately want to write a thousand essays on it, but that’s where we’re at with this one.

name: Carol Chen
review: I started reading this book in 2016, during my first year in France and its accompanied initiation into a passion for travelling alone. This book encouraged my wanderlust, for it described a world of strange yet alluring cities to discover --- a whole new world.I finished it a few years later, when I am much less impressionable and more critically minded. It appealed a lot less to my imagination of the exotic and lent itself more to an orientalist critique. The writing is simple and elegant. I am just not very interested by it.

name: Gurldoggie
review: An enchanting travelogue of non-existent cities, as described by Marco Polo to his patron Kublai Khan. The cities are by turns philosophical and preposterous, each one a koan. A quick read, but one that lingers.

name: Ad Pluijmers
review: This is the first book from Italo Calvino that I read and it didn’t appeal to me. I really had difficulty making sense of the series of short, vague chapters, written in poem-style (not on rhyme though…). Even after subsequently reading some (of the very many) very positive 5-star Goodreads reviews the real meaning of the writer didn’t become clear to me.Perhaps I’ll have to read it again sometime…

name: Nancy Ross
review: Lovely lyrical language...lack of plot. Having just audited a class about the development of cities in the colonial Americas, I found it fascinating in some ways and utterly mystifying in others. Strange but compelling little book.

name: Anna Ceddia
review: Dopo la trilogia (che è tra i miei libri preferiti), volevo fortemente leggere un’altra opera di Italo Calvino. Devo dire che lo stile di città invisibili è abbastanza diverso dall’opera precedentemente letta e perciò unico. Per questo motivo, credo di non riuscire a paragonare le due opere.

name: Len
review: Αφηγήματα των πόλεων που ο ίδιος ο Calvino περιγράφει με τρόπο που θα ήθελες να ξέρεις σε ποιές πόλεις αναφέρεται και δομή που δεν αντιλαμβάνεσαι πλήρως διαβάζοντας το, παρά μόνο αν αναζητήσεις περαιτέρω ανάλυση.

name: Tyler C
review: A perfect length short novel, packed full of vivid stories that hardly take a page or more. Really an accomplishment of writing more than anything, with uniqueness that makes it feel like 50 books rather than one.

name: Snorri Vignisson
review: Las hana fyrst fyrir nokkrum árum síðan og fannst hún bara ágæt en alltaf verið mikill Calvino aðdáandi. Síðan neyddist ég til að kaupa annað eintak þar sem þessi bók er alltaf að poppa upp í undirmeðvitund minni og kalla á meiri athygli... Held að það sé merki um góða bók.

name: Katie
review: Why is everyone not reading/teaching/writing about/learning this book? Calvino takes your breath away with his now fanciful, now dark, always insightful musings on human nature and the intimately related natures of cities and empire. So. Good.

name: Micheline
review: I read this book in parts. I would read his description of a place. Then I would meditate while imagining that city in my mind. Walking thought it. Catching its inhabitants in every day chores. This is a great book for meditation.

name: Lilly
review: this is one of my favorite books! I love the surrealism, the beautiful self-contained descriptions, and the ongoing commentary on the strangeness of the world throughout. That said this book is exclusively world-building so if that's not your thing might not be a worthwhile read.

name: Hannah Thaggard
review: This book is gorgeous, truly beautiful, but I just wanted more. Like so many interesting ideas and concepts to expand on, I just felt like I was missing something. I don’t know, I just felt like there was something missing that wasn’t being delivered

name: Adriano Pugno
review: Un libro che mette le vertigini e lo fa nel modo più soave possibile. Calvino crea mondi troppo belli per (non) essere veri. Uno di quei libri da portarsi dietro nello zaino e rileggere almeno una volta al mese.

name: Simone Faustino
review: Muito da complexidade do mundo e das relações humanas transparece na descrição de cidades fantásticas, enquanto acompanhamos o diálogo entre Marco Polo e o imperador Kublai Khan. Viajamos de carona pelas metrópoles, em um exercício de memória e imaginação. Curiosamente, todas têm nomes de mulher.

name: Rafael
review: I might not be able to understand its complete meanings, but I found this reading to be a little repetitive, though I understood the point in being that way.Nonetheless, I'm glad I read it, it being for a faculty work.

name: Nicky
review: I have mixed feelings about this book, and feel perhaps this is one I should have read rather than listening to.I love an experiment in form, and Calvino is a master at this. This was interesting and fun but felt somehow unsatisfying, in the same way as a lot of SF which is all worldbuilding and no story.I may revisit in future.

name: Hamsini
review: This is a small book, yet a slow and rich read. Each city and its characteristics will remind different readers of different cities. For me, it's Delhi. Will keep going back to these invisible, hidden cities to find a renewed meaning every single time I reopen a page.

name: Alessandra
review: Ascoltato in forma audiolibro, probabilmente non permette di cogliere appieno la profondità delle innumerevoli metafore presenti all'interno del testo. Sicuramente da rileggere per coglierne i significati più profondi, comunque ad un primo ascolto già molto interessante!

name: Meghan
review: The cities might be different cities or all part of the same city. Or maybe time is fluid and they aren't all in the same time period. It's repetitive, but the language is descriptive and, in spots, almost poetic. There's not much story but it's a good read if you just love words.

name: Paul Morris
review: Ok it was cute for a few pages and then became simply monotonous and plotless. Neat descriptions here and there, but can’t see why this book is so highly rated. I almost have up, but since it was a short book I hurriedly finished. Maybe I’m just not getting it?

name: Nuria Romeu
review: Además de que está muy bien escrito me sorprende la capacidad de inventar nuevos universos y posibilidades. Leer a Calvino es como ingresar en un mundo nuevo. Igual, no me tocó ninguna fibra interior, siento como que faltó algo. Pero es un libro muy lindo

name: Bárbara Coutinho
review: Es un libro muy bonito, me resultó un poco difícil de leer porque requiere concentración total y es muy abstracto. De todas formas lo recomiendo.It's a beautiful book, quite hard to read because it required full attention, but definitely would recommend it.

name: Dora Prieto
review: A classic that holds up (if you can look past the intense patriarchal/racist lens, which at times I couldn't). But the descriptions are beautiful and concise in their anecdotal nature, and I love the inventive concept and structure of having a novel of short chapters describing different cities.

name: A. B.
review: Beautiful. Took some time to get used to at first, but a second flip-through and rereading a few sections convinced me of its merits. Undescribable, of course, like Calvino, but a great journey through travel, cities, and human imagination.

name: San
review: với mình thì đây là một quyển sách hơi khó đọc, nhưng khu bắt đầy quen thì cứ đọc liên tục để được khám phá trí tưởng tượng kì vĩ của tác giả, mỗi thành phố 1 câu chuyện không trùng lặp, Italo kể chuyện đô thị nhưng cũng nói về chuyện nhân sinh, thật tài tình !!

name: manel queiroz
review: read for my degree’s final project.fragmented and thought-provoking, not only was this an interesting read but it was also full of ideias and quotes that will be very useful for my thesis. calvino’s writing is fantastical and i wish i analyzed it in class.

name: Giorgia Imbriani
review: Il bello di Calvino è che riesce a descrivere mondi inesistenti, fantastici, impossibili (invisibili no, perché invisibili? si vedono benissimo, basta chiudere gli occhi). Tante brevi descrizioni di città fantastiche: divorate.

name: Brice Foster
review: Somehow both a very easy read and very cerebral. Lots of interesting thoughts here described in easy-to-understand language that unlike a lot of philosophy centric stories explains its ideas without getting bogged down in them.

name: Sarah
review: I'm glad that I took my time reading this! It wasn't at all what I was expecting – there wasn't really a plot or a story that you had to follow, but I really enjoyed the detailed, almost magical descriptions of the locations. I can imagine that this would be a good book to read on holiday.

name: Swastik
review: I think this book is meant to be read aloud or to be listened to being narrated by a good narrator. This book makes you travel through cities, time, worlds, psychology, philosophy and most importantly, yourself.

name: Ilaria
review: Pur avendolo studiato all'università, non l'ho apprezzato come avrei dovuto e voluto. Purtroppo io e Calvino abbiamo un rapporto di amore e odio: anche se le sue idee mi piacciono, la loro realizzazione mi lascia molte volte indifferente.

name: Carlos Torres
review: Un libro interesante y muy imaginativo, aunque su defecto (desde mi punto de vista) es que carece de corazón y pasión, lo que termina volviendo la lectura un poco repetitiva y lenta. En este tipo de relato Wilde combinaba la imaginación y la emoción genialmente.

name: Daniela Tordoya
review: La cantidad de reflexiones que se puede obtener a partir de las "simples" estructuras y composiciones de distintas ciudades, acompañadas de una historia envolvente, me parece increíble. Un libro que volvería a leer, sin duda.

name: Ray
review: It's a lot. This book definitely took time for me to digest and read through. I wasn't so amazed by it as others but I felt connected to the themes because of the time I've spent in NYC.If you're not good with metaphors you'll need a buddy to read this one.

name: Diana
review: Philosophical wanderings through cities of speculative fabulations. Cities of memory, myth, imagination, and objects of social and political commentary. A conversation between Marco Polo and Kublai Khan.

name: redbird_fan
review: I do not understand why anyone would enjoy reading this.🥴I suppose the same could be said for much of what I enjoy reading.15 or 20 pages was enough for me. Seems like a book where it is supposed to be so good, that people rate it highly to look culturally adept.

name: Elisa
review: 也许真的是他最好的作品了，每段都可以连读三遍。末附Pasolini的短评也写得不错，是那种读后会让人立刻又想把书再读一遍的文章。恐怕正如文中所说：“老年”（一种充满经验但失去了illusion的状态）卡尔维诺的文学在解脱了现实关怀（的illusion）赋予它的作用和义务之后（这并不意味着他失去了政治观点，他只是不再有义务将一切用同一种时间线性地连接起来），终于成为了一座可以随意取用的废弃宝藏，而这时他从中取出的才是他需要的。（但至于他说所有城市的根源归根结底都是Platonism，啊，这应该很容易看出来吧。）

name: Sam
review: Felt like reading the same page 100 times... very romantically written but there was literally nothing here to keep you interested in what was going on... had to really force myself to finish this one

name: Stephen
review: This book was wonderful—literally full of wonder. A series of conversations between Kublai Kahn and Marco Polo, it’s collection of stories, or fables, about the cities that Marco has visited. Through metaphor and meaning, each city reveals something about life, death, and being.

name: Nick Fleming
review: I don't usually gravitate towards literary fiction BUT a) this was in a box on the side of the road and b) I haven't left Melbourne in two and a half years, so sue me. A must read if you're in the market for some mental adventures/possess a bleeding desire for Kublai Khan fanfiction. Cheerio

name: Tizi
review: Nulla togliere a Calvino che tratta temi affascinanti quali la memoria, il desiderio nostalgico, il senso di disfacimento e la futilità delle cose. Tuttavia, le città si mischiano tra di loro e nessun racconto è stato memorabile, pochi quelli che ho apprezzato. Lettura semplice. Voto 2.5

name: Ylenia Biscalchin
review: Sinceramente fino a poco più di metà libro non trovavo piacere nel leggere questo libro così enigmatico e complesso. Poi dopo poco la metà la rivelazione e il libro cambia totalmente piega e significato diventando il capolavoro che tanto denotano.

name: NunoAvelar
review: Esperava mais de Calvino. Um livro em que presa a estrutura e não o enredo.Descritivo q.b. de n mundos imaginários, mas sem enredo. O único enredo é entre capitulos, onde existe a troca de diálogo entre Marco Polo e Khan.

name: Simon Vandereecken
review: Un recueil très spécial, rempli de villes imaginaires qui nous fait voyager entre des ruelles et des paysages totalement inconnus et mystérieux. On enchaine les villes et les décors alors que nos têtes se remplissent d’images et l’on se met à rêver quelques instants…

name: Stella
review: Onestamente avevo aspettate altissime per quella che si è dimostrata una delusione, molto creativo come concetto, ma onestamente la straordinarietà è così tanto normalizzata da divenire null'altro che noia. Peccato

name: Camilla Colombi
review: A tratti lento e confuso, ma allo stesso tempo geniale e penetrante. Non avevo capito la modalità di lettura, dopo averla capita ho realizzato il genio. Bello, un classico da leggere almeno una volta nella vita.

name: DD Burlin
review: Fanciful, yet tedious. Page after page of made-up cities. Is there a metaphor I'm just altogether missing? It's like the author just wrote these scraps as a writing exercise and then thought that they would make for a great book. It just didn't work for me.

name: Alexa
review: I’m convinced this was just a very poetic lucid dream. It read like a mix between Stefon’s New York hottest clubs but instead of clubs it was cities, and what limbo in Inception feels like in words. I really don’t know how else to explain it.

name: Estela-Marie
review: Every Calvino book opens my eyes to the possibilities of thought. To what can be achieved in writing. This particular book offered philosophies behind places(cities) that I have yet to fully explore. It’s given my mind a space to consider how to travel and engage in this world.

name: Marie Polega
review: I didn't really get this book. Some of it made sense, some of the language and descriptions were really pretty, and some went over my head. It's really creative though, and imaginative in the descriptions of the cities. It was thought-provoking too.

name: Geoff
review: Every time I come home from walks through the woods now and am presenting my hands for my cat to smell, I think of myself as Marco Polo presenting to Kublai Khan to tell him tales of where I've been without speaking.

name: Adrián Viéitez
review: El camino de abstracción que propone aquí Calvino tiene la virtud de lo específico: es posible que la ciudad sea un tropo, pero si uno se detiene y escucha, entiende que más allá del tropo todavía existe la promesa de una ciudad.

name: Thomas Noriega
review: If you ever go to Venice, bring this book with you, and cherish Marco Polo's thousand domes and towers reflected on the lagoon, waiting behind each narrow alley, and inscribed in the faces of those you pass and meet. When you find your own Venice, Calvino will give you the language to describe it.

name: Jody
review: Still contemplating the book. Wish I had read in an English course as feel I must have missed much. Glad I didn’t read in an English course as feel teasing it apart would spoil much if it’s beauty. Definitely one to reread and savor.

name: Todd
review: I tried my best.. This just isn't the sort of book I enjoy. I don't know if it's the short story format or the mental exercise nature of it or what but it didn't work for me. I I mean, I appreciate what it's doing, but its not for me. I made it half way.

name: أحمد الدين
review: رائعة كالفينو، مدن متخيلة غير مرئية، تحكي الحكاية كما لو كانت حكاية ألف ليلة وليلة، يلعب ماركو بولو دور شهرزاد، وقبلاي خان دور شهريار، لكن بندية أكبر، يبدع كالفينو في الوصف فيجعل المكان أو المدينة هي المحرك لساكنيها، ويقدم تتابعات حكائيه لا مثيل لها.

name: Jessica Blevins
review: When a book inspires you to journal, take notes and spend hours researching art based on the text, that’s pretty magical. One of my favorite books and one I think I’ll return to again and again. Great for anyone interested in travel, psychology, humanity and history.

name: João
review: um dos livros mais bonitos que eu já li!!! descrições de cidades fantásticas com uma delicadeza e uma percepção incrível. as analogias feitas e o diálogo entre os únicos dois personagens são incríveis e não tem como não amar essa obra. vai se tornar meu novo livro de cabeceira. favoritado

name: Helen
review: کتاب رو از کتابخونه‌ی دوستم برداشتم و انتظار داشتم توی یه عصر تموم بشه. کتاب قشنگیه، خیال‌انگیز و سرشار از تصویرهای ذهنی. من زود خوندمش ولی حس میکنم برای لذت بردن از صور خیال باید آروم آروم کلمات رو مزه‌مزه کرد.

name: Chase Burghgrave
review: Through a fictional dialogue between Marco Polo and Kubla Khan, Calvino explores imagined cities, each more strange and fantastical than the last. Through exploring them we begin to see common themes between all cities. A dreamlike and bizarre book which is worth pondering.

name: Carol Soto
review: I Like MagicI love a good escape, especially through tiny details and innuendo. The canvas of Calvino is rich and timeless, so timeless that you reach through centuries and ancient myths.

name: Salomé
review: The little dialogues between Marco Polo and Kublai Khan are so well done. They never come off as didactic. And I love layering this meditation on space through a fictitious, enigmatic, yet sensible exchange.

name: Michaela
review: I greatly enjoyed reading this book and would gladly read it again. It is a perfect combination of fantastical whimsy and careful construction. There is a lot to unpack in how this book is put together and I have not even started.

name: Allison
review: I enjoyed this and am certain much was lost on me. It falls loosely in the category of fiction (perhaps adding the tag “experimental?”), though it lacks plot, but eloquently describes the ebb and flow of life through the medium of cities.

name: Ross
review: This is my second Calvino. His writing is unique and I think there is a lot to be appreciated, but for some reason my expectations don't seem to meet the hype. Its certainly a 'me' problem, I expect that I'm just overthinking it.

name: Elisabeth Bienvenue
review: A magnificent and truly unique book which reads like a prose poem. Calvino’s imagined cities paint a poignant picture of the world around us, and the writing is leisurely and beautiful. It is a piece of writing which deserves to be read over and over again.

name: SAMKyrie
review: From the beautiful beaches of Hawaii all the cities feel so far away. Probably not the best zeitgeist or ortgeist to read this one. Though the writing is undoubtedly beautiful none of it seemed to resonate in the special way books can

name: Timo
review: Again a book which existence leaves me doubting as basically the whole book is just descriptions of imaginary cities and would have worked a lot better with some illustrations and with less complicated language.

name: Carla Garduño
review: 3 (1/2) Tiene frases acá muy bonitas y que invitan a reflexionar sobre la manera en que construimos y vivimos las ciudades. Pero no les voy a mentir yo no soy muy fan de ese estilo de los viajes de Marco Polo y de repente se me hizo un poco tediosón. Lo que más me gustó fue la nota preliminar jeje

name: Theresa
review: Marco Polo and his travels to imaginary places?I want illustrations!This is my second Calvino, and the second of his books I did not finish. Too esoteric for me right now . . . maybe another time.

name: Trevor Kidd
review: Beautiful imagery describing fictitious cities, framed as a conversation between Marco Polo and Kublai Khan. I'll be the first to admit I didn't get everything I could have out of it (apparently the structure is mathematical) but I enjoyed it a lot as an audiobook.

name: Red
review: Calvino has managed to write a story for cityplanners it seems. They have a lot to choose when they are in lack of inspiration. He has written a story abouth death and how that is and where.It is furthermore a way to contemplate the possesion of something or someone. In particular a person.

name: Giuliana
review: La mayoría de los libros se presentan como una certeza; este, como un misterio. No tengo dudas de que en los próximos años volveré a leer Las ciudades invisibles intentando entender no la trama de la obra, sino mi (nuestra) propia relación con las ciudades, cada vez más expulsivas.

name: Christopher
review: This is a book I think I will need to read a second time, some day. Whether my rating will increase or decrease over time remains to be seen. For now, I can say it contains some beautifully turned phrases and imagery that feels emotionally well defined, if perhaps visually difficult to articulate.

name: Patricio
review: Creo que soy muy fan de Ítalo Calvino. Todas sus obras son fantásticas. Del Barón Rampante me quedé hablando meses.Este libro está bueno pero no sé si me gustó tanto, aún así es de Calvino y eso es una garantía.

name: Sarah
review: This is a book of dreams and impressions. There's no real story, just a series of thought experiments, but that impressionistic writing makes this book relatively unique. I'm sure I'll revisit it again in the future.

name: Nny_clnn
review: Finalmente l’ho finito. Ci ho messo davvero un’eternità.Penso che le città invisibili sia uno di quei libri di cui non riesco a farmi un’opinione. Non dico che non mi sia piaciuto, però non dico neanche che mi è piaciuto 🥹Non saprei, Italo Calvino rimane per me un grande BHO

name: Artur Cardelino
review: Another great book that shows Calvino ability to create stuff, and imagine wonderful things out of thin air. Great setting and it feels like you need to read it at different times to learn something new and also reflect on different topics as you grow older.

name: Sanne
review: I loved how this book meandered through city descriptions, how the book was both dream-like and down to earth. I read this book out loud to myself and the cadence was beautiful. This is on my reread (out loud to myself) list for sure.

name: Kristian Greiner
review: Sometimes a book doesn't even need to have a plot, but is able to move and make do with only a situation, and its done in a surreal, anachronistic and ethereal way that, perhaps worst of all, makes it look easy. Its pretty damn good. Really damn good. Damn good damn damn good.... damn. Good.

name: Harry Goodwin
review: A series of lovely vignettes, which at best are absolutely scintillating, at least-best a little too wispy and hazy. A lovely literary palette cleanser, like the ginger at a sushi place (I realise that sounds like a bit of an insult...)

name: Jo
review: One of those books where I have to stop and think... What did I just read? It felt like something between a piece of philosophy on what it is to be an outsider in a city, and a compilation of fantasy novel city openers. The writing was beautiful : this is something I should have read on a plane.

name: Phoenix Parris
review: no plot, just vibes.my favourite parts were definitely the conversations between Marco and the Khan.you can definitely apply the city descriptions to any big city and it works as a great commentary on its flaws and beauties.

name: Duarte Cabral
review: "The only author I've read that gives Borges a run for his money in regards to the amount of parsable, philosophical, dreamy mindfuckery he can shove inside a single page. Kind of makes you wish all books were like this."

name: Julia
review: just finished calvino’s invisible cities and it weirdly helped w my homesickness. it’s the kind of book that you have to digest in small bites but it’s so worth it. something about how it’s filled w imagination but is able to express subtle emotions really gets to me. 5/5 tbh

name: Waldo
review: "ეძებო და მიაგნო იმას, ვინც და რაც შუაგულ ჯოჯოხეთში ჯოჯოხეთი არ არის" - ამაზე ნაკლები მიზანი არ უნდა გქონდეს ადამიანს.მაგრამ, რადგან "სიტყვები შლის მეხსიერებაში შენახულ სურათებს", ამ წიგნზე არასოდეს ვილაპარაკებ :))

name: Mujeeb Otho
review: 55 fictitious cities that are narrated by Polo, many of which can be read as parables or meditations on culture, language, time, memory, death, or the general nature of human experience.Something different i read based on the imagination.

name: Steve
review: I sweet little meditation, examining human foibles and societies through fantastical prose poems. It's a quick and charming read that will stay with you given its strong symbolism, surreality, and sense of playfulness.Deeply fun, interesting and revisitable.

name: Niki
review: Did not care about this book for a second, very repetitive and boring. I read 50 pages of this and then I skimmed through the rest. I don’t ever want to have to read another description of a “dreamy” and “unique” city again.

name: Arthur Goldblatt
review: Like entering a dreamscape that spans millennia and contains every place that’s existed, real or imagined. Makes me consider cities as entities with beating hearts, weathered visages, and sinewy muscles.

name: Ryan McGranaghan
review: This book changed my conception of what the novel could be. It's an imaginative form and each section, and each city within each section, is exhilarating in what it made me notice and become aware of.

name: David
review: Calvino's style - a dreamlike, lyrical prose - is engrossing. Though I read it and despair of ever being able to write nearly as well, I cannot help but be swept up in the beauty of his writing. William Weaver's translation from Italian is magnificent.

name: DanHus
review: One of the most wonderfully warm books I have ever read. Italo Calvinos beautiful prose inspires such a sense of childlike wonder and comfort that feel like being wrapped in a cozy blanket in front of a fire. A book I'll be revisting for a long, long time.

name: Em Jay
review: Obviously as wonderful as when I first read it. And of the fifty year old stuff I've read recently the one that could have been written yesterday.Never sure about the translation though. Why would you keep tins in the refrigerator?

name: Shena
review: "Memory's images, once they are fixed in words, are erased," Polo said. "Perhaps I am afraid of losing Venice all at once, if I speak of it. Or perhaps, in speaking of other cities, I have already lost it, little by little."

name: Cole Holderjano
review: A very difficult book to review. Parts of Calvino’s writing are brilliant, at other points I’m not sure even he understands what he is getting at. Overall this book has amazing prose, and makes many good points, but it falls a bit short in presenting a cohesive, insightful message.

name: Cameron
review: Sumptuous. Exquisitely written, but plotless. Glittering, a unique book Written from the invented memory of Marco Polo in discussion with Kublai Khan of a series of invented cities of glitter and Gold and memory and desire.

name: Matilde
review: A história do livro deixa-nos a pensar em muitas coisas, no entanto, para entender a escrita é necessário uma abstração do "normal" da parte do leitor, que nos leva um lugar sem fim na nosaa imaginação.

name: Dylan
review: the idea of this book sounds great, the actual book is alright. for my interests in the history of nationalism, this book is a natural companion to Benedict Anderson’s Imagined Communities, and I can’t help but think Calvino could teach nationalism scholars a thing or two

name: Ilan A
review: At times lovely—creative in its structure, the parables fantastic and dreamlike (mr Calvino clearly has a beautiful mind <3)… but at times a bit didactic, repetitive, and heavy-handed (dare I say sometimes approaching the realm of platitude) in its philosophical mic-drops.

name: Pria
review: Imma b honest, I don’t think I got this book, but it was a nice palette cleanser after sniffing the rank and stinky mental filth of Houllebecq. Nice pretty descriptions, very few pages, very simple prose. Put me to sleep!

name: Dawson Escott
review: Didn't even know a book could be written like this and it's crazy good. Part of me does wish it stayed married to some kind of "historical realism" a little longer, but as it strays away radically it's still very cool. Tons of creativity throughout.

name: zoe
review: if you ask me to retell the story of a single city, i won't be able to give you an answer.. but i do like most of the writing in here and the overall message of trying to find something in the middle of all these nothingness

name: Jose Felipe
